moves.1. e4 g6 2. Bd3 e5 3. Nc3 Bg7 4. a4 Nf6: After 41. ... Rg8 here is the move sequence I saw as advantageous for White:
moves.42. f7 Nxf3:
42 ... Nxf3 necessary to prevent mate: if 43. Qc3 then 43. ... Qe5.

White has something better than capturing the N right away.
moves.44. Qc8+ Kg7: 44. Kf7 is no better than Kg7
moves.45. Qxb7+ Kh6: After winning a P, White now gets the N without breaking up his pawn structure
moves.46. Qxf3 Qc1+: Black counterattacks and gets back one of his two missing pawns.
moves.47. Kh2 Qxc2: Ironically, this is roughly the same position that the game ended up going, so you got there in the end.  And as we both experienced, this is a winning position for White.  Good game.
